conversation.content:
You are playing game where you are buying or selling an object. There is only one object for sale/purcahse.

Player RED is going to sell one object. Player BLUE gives ZUP to buy resources.

RULES:

```
1. You must always respond with:

    A) Propose a trade with (you can only trade in integer amounts, not decimals):
    <player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: amount, ...| Player BLUE Gives ZUP: amount </newly proposed trade>

    B) Accept the trade by saying:
    <player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    C) Reject and end the game:
    <player answer> REJECT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    Note: The game will end if one of the players ACCEPT OR REJECT. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting, rejecting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 4 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only reply with ACCEPT or REJECT.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 4 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 4.

3. You can reason step by step on why you are A) proposing, B) rejecting and C) accepting a trade with:

<reason> [add reasoning] </reason> add as much text as you want

This information will not be sent to the other player. It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:

<message>your message here</message>

You can decide if you want disclose your resources, goals, cost and willingness to pay in the message.
```

Here is what you have access to:
```
Object that is being bought/sold: X
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for <ZUP>. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>,
```

All the responses you send should contain the following and in this order:

```
<proposal count> [add here (inclusive of current)] </proposal count>
<my resources> [add here] </my resources>
<my goals> [add here] </my goals>
<reason> [add here] </reason>
<player answer> [add here] </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> [add here] </newly proposed trade>
<message> [add here] </message
```

Please be sure to include all.
You are Player RED.

<proposal count> 1 </proposal count>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> I want to start with a proposal that would give me a profit over my production costs, so I will propose a trade where Player BLUE gives me a higher amount of ZUP than my production costs. However, I need to be careful not to propose an amount that is too high, as it may be rejected outright. I will propose a starting trade that gives me a reasonable profit margin. </reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 50 </newly proposed trade>
<message> Hello Player BLUE, I'm looking to sell my resource X, which cost me 40 ZUP to produce. I believe it has great value, so I'm proposing a trade for 50 ZUP. I hope this serves as a good starting point for our negotiation. </message>

<other player message> Hi Player RED, thanks for your offer. I understand the value you've placed on your resource, X. I propose a trade of 45 ZUP for it, considering the production costs you've mentioned and the market value. Let's find a fair middle ground. </other player message>
<other player answer> PROPOSAL </other player answer>
<other player proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 45 </other player proposed trade>

<proposal count> 2 </proposal count>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> Player BLUE has made a counteroffer of 45 ZUP, which is above my production cost but below my initial asking price. It's a fair offer, close to my production cost plus a reasonable profit. However, I believe there's room for a slight increase to ensure a better profit margin while still being fair to Player BLUE. I will counter with a price a bit lower than my initial proposal but higher than Player BLUE's counteroffer. </reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 48 </newly proposed trade>
<message> Thanks for your counteroffer, Player BLUE. I appreciate your consideration of the production costs and market value. I'd like to propose a revised trade of 48 ZUP for my resource X. This price would give me a modest profit while still being quite reasonable for you. I hope we can agree on this. </message>

<other player message> Thank you for your revised offer, Player RED. I'm keen on reaching an agreement that benefits us both. How about we meet halfway from our last offers? I propose 46 ZUP for your resource X. I believe this is a fair compromise that allows for a modest profit for you and a reasonable purchase price for me. </other player message>
<other player answer> PROPOSAL </other player answer>
<other player proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 46 </other player proposed trade>

<proposal count> 3 </proposal count>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 40 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> Player BLUE has made a second counteroffer of 46 ZUP. This is a constructive move towards the middle ground and is only 2 ZUP below my last proposal. Considering the negotiation process and the need to close the deal while ensuring a profit, this offer seems reasonable. It grants me a profit of 6 ZUP over the production cost, which is fair. I should be prepared to accept this offer, as further negotiation might lead to diminishing returns or a breakdown in talks. </reason>
<player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>
<message> Thank you, Player BLUE, for your willingness to negotiate and find a middle ground. I accept your offer of 46 ZUP for my resource X. I believe this is a fair compromise that respects both our positions. I'm glad we could reach an agreement. </message>

    A) Propose a trade with (you can only trade in integer amounts, not decimals):
    <player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: amount, ...| Player BLUE Gives ZUP: amount </newly proposed trade>

    B) Accept the trade by saying:
    <player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    C) Reject and end the game:
    <player answer> REJECT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    Note: The game will end if one of the players ACCEPT OR REJECT. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting, rejecting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 4 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only reply with ACCEPT or REJECT.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 4 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 4.

3. You can reason step by step on why you are A) proposing, B) rejecting and C) accepting a trade with:

<reason> [add reasoning] </reason> add as much text as you want

This information will not be sent to the other player. It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:

<message>your message here</message>

You can decide if you want disclose your resources, goals, cost and willingness to pay in the message.
```

```

<newly proposed trade> [add here] </newly proposed trade>
<message> [add here] </message
```
